required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Multicenter Prospective Study of Quality of Life in Adult Scoliosis
clinical_study.official_title: A Multicenter Prospective Study of Quality of Life in Adult Scoliosis

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases (NIAMS)
Hospital for Special Surgery, New York

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a multicenter study evaluating the effectiveness of nonoperative and operative treatments. The investigators wish to identify important clinical and radiographic determinants of outcomes in the management of adults with symptomatic lumbar scoliosis (ASLS).
Note: Enrollment was complete July 2014. National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases (NIAMS) funding ended 2/28/17. We continue to follow enrolled subjects while we seek additional funding to follow all subjects through 8 years.

detailed_description.textblock:
Specific Aim #1: Compare the outcomes of surgery and nonoperative treatment in patients aged 40 to 80 with ASLS defined as a lumbar curve with a coronal Cobb measurement ≥ 30°, and either of the following: Oswestry (ODI) score of 20 or more; or Scoliosis Research Society Quality of Life instrument (SRS-QOL) score of 4.0 or less, in the domains of pain, function and/or appearance.
Specific Aim #2: Evaluate the impact of patient factors (age, gender, socioeconomic status, education) and comorbidities [mental health, body mass index (BMI) and bone mineral density (BMD)] on adverse events and treatment outcomes for both the nonoperative and operative arms. Incorporate these variables into a prediction model to help identify those patients most likely to benefit from either a surgical or nonoperative approach

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: There were 2 cohorts: Randomized and Observational, each with an operative and non-operative arm.

primary_outcome.measure: Scoliosis Research Society Quality of Life Questionnaire (SRS QOL) Subscore
primary_outcome.description: Change was calculated as the SRS QOL Subscore value at 2-year minus the value at Baseline for Randomized Cohort (Intent-to-Treat analysis). SRS QOL Subscore value range is 1 to 5, where 5 is the best score and 1 is the worst score possible.

primary_outcome.measure: Scoliosis Research Society Quality of Life (SRS QOL) Subscore
primary_outcome.description: Change was calculated as the SRS QOL Subscore value at 2-year as-treated follow-up minus the value at Baseline in the Observational cohort. SRS QOL Subscore value range is 1 to 5, where 5 is the best score and 1 is the worst score possible.

secondary_outcome.description: Change was calculated as the ODI score at 2-year minus the value at Baseline in Randomized Cohort (intent-to-treat analysis). ODI score range is 0 to 100, where 0 is the best score and 100 is the worst score possible.
Change was calculated as the ODI score at 2-year as treated follow-up minus the value at baseline. ODI score range is 0 to 100, where 0 is the best score and 100 is the worst score possible.

intervention.description: Surgical intervention as appropriate for adults with symptomatic lumbar scoliosis
Non operative intervention as appropriate for treatment of adults with symptomatic lumbar scoliosis such as: injections, medications, physical therapy, etc.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- aged 40 to 80 years with
- ASLS defined as lumbar curve with a coronal Cobb measurement ≥ 30°, and either of the following: Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) score ≥ 20 or SRS-QOL score ≤ 4.0 in the domains of pain, function and/or appearance.
- If assigned to surgical intervention (by randomization or patient preference), the intervention plan would include, at a minimum, the Cobb levels of the Thoracolumbar/lumbar spine.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Substantial cardiac, pulmonary, renal or metabolic disease that, in the judgment of the surgical team, would preclude performing an operative procedure without undue risk of morbidity and mortality
- Concomitant high-grade spondylolisthesis (Grade 3)
- Prior thoracic or multiple level lumbar laminectomy or decompression [single or two level lumbar decompression (e.g., herniated disc) will not be an exclusion]
- Prior thoracic or lumbar fusion
- Osteoporosis evidence by a dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) T-score <-3.0 at hip or lumbar spine for patients considered to be at risk (post menopausal females, males > 60 years of age, steroid dependent rheumatoid arthritics, status post organ transplantation, etc.). Patients may be randomized prior to obtaining DEXA results. Non Surgical patients may initiate non surgical treatments prior to completion of DEXA (if required) as non surgical treatments will not affect DEXA results but DEXA must be completed and results entered within 3 months of enrollment. Surgical patient must have DEXA prior to surgical intervention.
- Neuromuscular scoliosis (e.g., spinal muscular atrophy, cerebral palsy, Parkinson's Disease, post-polio syndrome, Charcot Marie Tooth disease)
- Congenital scoliosis in the lumbar spine. Congenital anomalies of the cervical or thoracic spine are acceptable.
- Spine tumor, infection or connective tissue disorder
- Cognitively impaired or unable/unwilling to comply with follow-up
- Pregnancy or planning on conceiving during time of study involvement
- Ankylosing Spondylitis
- Past history of vertebroplasty or kyphoplasty of the thoracic or lumbar spine

clinical_study.keyword: Symptomatic 40-80 y/o w/lumbar Cobb of 30 degrees
All Participants must be reasonable surgical candidate at enrollment

participants_list.participants: 6 patients crossed over to non-operative intervention.
1 withdrew. 15 (45%) crossed over to operative treatment.
4 missed visits. 6 withdrew. 6 (5%) crossed over to operative treatment.
1 missed visit. 1 withdrew. 1 deceased. 24 patients (80%) underwent surgery.
1 missed visit. 1 withdrew. 21 (64%) crossed over to operative treatment.
8 missed visits. 9 withdrew. 14 (13%) crossed over to operative treatment.

baseline.population: Symptomatic adult lumbar scoliosis patients (ages 40-80, lumbar Cobb measurement >30° and Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) >20 or Scoliosis Research Society-22 <4.0) with no prior history of scoliosis surgery from 9 North American centers were enrolled in randomized or observational cohorts to evaluate surgery versus nonoperative treatment.

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Scoliosis Research Society (SRS) Subscore
measure.description: Scores range from 1 (worst score) to 5 (best score).

measure.title: SRS Pain Domain
measure.description: Scores range from 1 (worst score) to 5 (best score).

measure.title: SRS Function Domain
measure.description: Scores range from 1 (worst score) to 5 (best score).

measure.title: SRS Self-image Domain
measure.description: Scores range from 1 (worst score) to 5 (best score).

measure.title: SRS Mental Health Domain
measure.description: Scores range from 1 (worst score) to 5 (best score).

measure.title: Oswestry Disability Index (ODI)
measure.description: Scores range from 100 (worst score) to 0 (best score).

measure.title: Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) Back Pain
measure.description: Scores range from 10 (worst score) to 0 (best score).

measure.title: Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) Leg Pain
measure.description: Scores range from 10 (worst score) to 0 (best score).

measure.title: Short form-12 (SF-12) Mental Component Score
measure.description: Percentiles range from 0 to 100 with 'norm' being 50.

measure.title: SF-12 Physical Component Score
measure.description: Percentiles range from 0 to 100 with 'norm' being 50.

measure.title: Lumbar Cobb Angle
measure.description: Lumbar Cobb angle is the measurement of the scoliosis (curve in the coronal plane) measured in degrees. Normal is 0.

measure.title: Lumbar Lordosis (T12-Sacrum)
measure.description: Lumbar lordosis is the sagittal plane measurement of T12 to S1 in degrees. Mean for normal adults is 64 degrees +/- 10 degrees based on 'An analysis of sagittal spinal alignment in 100 asymptomatic middle and older aged volunteers' published in SPINE, Vol 20, number 12, pp 1351-1358 in 1995.

measure.title: Sagittal balance (C7 to Sacrum plumb)
measure.description: Measured in mm from mid body C7 to front of plumb in sagittal plane. Negative value indicates C7 plumb falls BEHIND sacrum. Ideal would be 0mm.

measure.title: Coronal balance
measure.description: Measure (in mm) mid body C7 to mid Sacrum plumb in coronal plane, Values reported in absolute values. Ideal = 0mm.

measure.title: Pelvic Incidence-Lumbar Lordosis Mismatch
measure.description: Mathematical difference between pelvic incidence and lumbar lordosis radiographic measurements in degrees. Differences > 10 degrees correlates with worse patient reported outcomes.

measure.title: Body Mass Index
measure.description: Normal adult BMI is 18.5 to 24.9

class.title: t-score -2.5 or worse (or vertebral compression fx

measure.title: Duration of leg symptoms
measure.description: Length of time patient reported having Leg symptoms at time of enrollment. If no leg symptoms, patient reported 0 months.

outcome.population: All randomized participants were included in analysis.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events were monitored/assessed in *each participant* from enrollment through study completion (end of funding), an average of 3.6 years. Specific amount of time for each individual is dependent upon when he/she entered the study and if/when they withdrew from the study.
reported_events.desc: Serious Adverse Events (SAE) were any events that resulted in: Death Hospitalization (new or prolonged) - Exception was hospitalization for index spinal deformity correction surgery. New disability (significant or permanent) Life threatening Unexpected but Reasonably Related to the Intervention

group.title: Surgical Intervention-As Treated AE's Occurring While Patient Was in Surgical Arm
group.description: Surgical intervention: Surgical intervention as appropriate for adults with symptomatic lumbar scoliosis. AE's are reported in the treatment arm (surgical or non-operative) patient was in at time of AE. A total of 171 patients had surgical intervention. This number includes non operative patients who crossed over to surgical intervention. Some patients spent time and had AEs in both treatment arms.

group.title: Non-Operative Intervention-As Treated AE's Occurring While Patient Was on Non Operative Arm
group.description: Non-operative intervention: Non operative intervention as appropriate for treatment of adults with symptomatic lumbar scoliosis such as: injections, medications, physical therapy, etc. AE's are reported in the treatment arm (surgical or non-operative) patient was in at time of AE. A total of 150 had non operative interventions.

event.description: Cardiac events that met NIAMS SAE criteria
GI events that met NIAMS SAE definitions

event.sub_title: Surgeries Unrelated to Adult Symptomatic Lumbar Scoliosis
event.description: Surgical events NOT related to adult scoliosis resulting new hospitalization
Misc events meeting NIAMS SAE criteria. Examples: Accidental injury, Dehydration, Altered metal status, Panic Attack, C spine stenosis, septic arthritis, anaphylactic shock, Addison's disease
Adult Scoliosis events meeting NIAMS SAE criteria. Examples: Lumbar stenosis, revision scoliosis spine surgeries)

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) Cancers
event.description: All Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) cancers occurring during the study were considered an SAE
Genitourinary events meeting NIAMS SAE reporting criteria
Pulmonary related events meeting NIAMS SAE reporting guidelines
Circulatory Events meeting NIAMS SAE criteria such as transient ischemic attack, cerebrovascular accident, Deep Vein Thrombosis, Pulmonary Embolism)
Shingles, Low B12, tinnitus, syncope, restless leg syndrome, cat bite, neuropathies d/t chemo, etc.
Ear, sinus, lyme disease, infected bites, herpes, etc.
Superficial and deep wound infections that did not require a hospitalization. If hospitalization was required, it was considered an SAE and is reported under SAEs

Spinal implant failure (rod fracture, hook/screw pull out, etc) that did not require revision surgery prior to end of funding. Those failures that were revised were considered SAE and reported under SAEs
Proximal breakdown that required revision surgery during funding is considered an SAE and reported as SAE.
Basal and squamous cell skin cancers

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
